Thomas Bodley to S
r

S
r
, I was in good hope, to have [seen]
yo
r
answear to my letter of
e [15 of]

c
. Yow knowe in yo
r
own [discre]
ti
o
, I had reason to expect it: an[d I]
thought
at
yow
in courtesie, yow w[ould]
somwhat content me. But seing it [is]
otherwise, I trust yow doe consid[er]
at yo
r
silence can not answear
e [cause]
of my complaint: I have mo[ved this]
councel to
at effect, as yow requ[est, that]
some order may be taken, for
e mo[nethlie]
paiment of yo
r
intertenment, and [for]
e arrerages. But their answear [and]
yo
r
demaund are farr disagreeing.
For
wheras
yow doe require after 3
li
a

day
their
allowance, they say is but 40
li

as

r

[mission]
Besides

at
e s
u
me [that is]
due for yo
r

at w
ch
is due fr
o

This is all
e answe ar
at I c
a
g[et]
at their handes: and I looke for no[ne other]
to all yo
r
demaundes, till some [ready]
satisfacti
o
be made unto them. [For, to]
tell yow
more plainely
somw
at
neerer
howe they [are]
affected, They doe repute themselves to [be a-]
par
a
tly deluded in all
e l
re
s
at
you
send, and
at yow thinke by de[vices]
to goe beyond them
in yo
r
actions
[which]
they say they will reforme,
and
w
ch
I do [signi]
fie thus plainely, to
e end yow ma[y]
c
o
sider, both what opinion they c
o
ceave [of yo
r
]
dealing, and w
at
meanes yow ar to [use]
to come in better favo
r
.
And so I lea[ve yow]
and c
o
mend yow to Gods preserv[ation]
